meanings.definition: Establish or organize as an institution.
meanings.sent1: The government decided to institutionalize new policies for public safety.
meanings.sent2: Universities often institutionalize certain traditions to maintain their culture.
meanings.sent3: It would be quite a sight to see a squirrel trying to institutionalize a nut-gathering routine.
meanings.sent4: Her passion for gardening was so strong that she managed to institutionalize it into a successful business.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's dedication to education was so inspiring that it seemed to institutionalize a love for learning in all her students.

meanings.definition: Make into or treat as an institution.
meanings.sent1: The community decided to institutionalize the local library as a hub for learning.
meanings.sent2: In some cultures, family values are institutionalized and highly respected.
meanings.sent3: It would be amusing to see a cat trying to institutionalize its favorite toy as a sacred object.
meanings.sent4: Her leadership skills were so remarkable that she seemed to institutionalize respect among her team.
meanings.sent5: The artist's unique style was so influential that it began to institutionalize a new trend in the art world.

meanings.definition: Place or confine in an institution, especially a mental health facility.
meanings.sent1: The court decided to institutionalize the patient for further evaluation.
meanings.sent2: In extreme cases, individuals may need to be institutionalized for their own safety.
meanings.sent3: It would be quite a scene to see a penguin trying to institutionalize itself in a tropical environment.
meanings.sent4: His fear of failure seemed to institutionalize him within the confines of his comfort zone.
meanings.sent5: The strict rules of the boarding school seemed to institutionalize discipline in all the students.
